title: 115_s717
content: The "POWER Act" aims to address high rates of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking by providing pro bono legal services. Efforts are needed at all levels to combat this violence and support victims. Pro bono legal assistance can help meet the high demand for services, including legal representation, emergency shelter, transportation, and childcare for victims of domestic violence. Research shows that legal aid reduces the likelihood of violence reoccurring and helps survivors move forward by obtaining protective orders. The American Bar Association emphasizes the importance of lawyers providing assistance regardless of their professional status. District courts should promote empowerment events to encourage lawyers to provide pro bono resources for victims of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. This will raise awareness and empower survivors to move forward with their lives. District courts are required to organize public events promoting pro bono legal services for survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. This includes partnering with various organizations to empower survivors and engage citizens in assisting them. Additionally, districts containing Indian tribes or tribal organizations must hold events every 2 years to increase pro bono legal services for Native American communities. District courts must organize public events promoting pro bono legal services for survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. Each chief judge has discretion in designing and implementing these events to maximize local impact and access to high-quality legal services. Chief judges are required to submit reports to the Director of the Administrative Office of the United States Courts detailing the public events conducted each year, with a compilation and summary submitted to Congress annually. The Administrative Office of the United States Courts will compile and summarize reports on public events promoting legal services for survivors of domestic violence, dating violence, sexual assault, and stalking. The reports will include an analysis of how each event aligns with the goals of the Act and suggestions for improving future events. Existing funds will be used to implement the requirements of the Act.
